title: Stephen Sondheim Has Died at 91
summary: Considered one of the greatest Broadway composers, he wrote lyrics for 'West Side Story' and 'Gypsy'. Stephen Sondheim, the legendary Broadway composer and songwriter behind "West Side Story," "Sweeney Todd" and "Into the Woods," died early Friday at his home in Roxbury, Conn. He was 91.

title: Omicron Coronavirus Variant Raises Questions Among Scientists
summary: Researchers are investigating whether mutations might make variant more infectious or evade immune response. The fast-spreading Omicron coronavirus variant recently identified in South Africa has virologists and health authorities on edge because of its many mutations, but much about its infectiousness and virulence remains unknown.

title: Stephen Sondheim (1930-2021)
summary: He so thoroughly revolutionized the Broadway musical that his name became synonymous with it..

title: New Covid-19 Travel Restrictions Rattle Airline Industry, Hits Shares
summary: U.S. to restrict travel from South Africa and seven other countries in southern Africa starting Monday. The U.S. said it would restrict travel from South Africa and seven other countries in southern Africa starting Monday, joining governments around the world seeking to stem the transmission of a new coronavirus variant identified in the region.

title: WTO Postpones First Meeting in Four Years Amid Variant Concerns
summary: World Trade Organization had already delayed gathering initially scheduled for June 2020. WASHINGTON-The World Trade Organization has decided to postpone a ministerial meeting scheduled to start Tuesday in Geneva, after dozens of nations restricted travel from southern Africa to prevent the transmission of a new coronavirus variant.

title: Lauren Boebert Apologizes to Muslims for Remarks About Ilhan Omar
summary: GOP lawmaker made a joke to supporters casting Democratic congresswoman as a possible suicide bomber. WASHINGTON-GOP Rep. Lauren Boebert apologized to Muslims on Friday for a joke casting Democratic Rep. Ilhan Omar as a possible suicide bomber that drew heavy criticism, with the top Republican in the House stepping in to try to tamp down the controversy.

title: The Omicron Variant Panic
summary: Markets fall, but the biggest danger is more government lockdowns.. Markets sold off worldwide on Friday after South Africa raised alarm about the new "variant of concern" that the World Health Organization named Omicron. The panic may be driven more by the fear of new government lockdowns and social distancing than by the variant itself.

title: Will Noncitizens Pick New York's Mayors?
summary: The City Council wants to let some 800,000 vote in local elections.. New York has been a dynamic city for a long time, and immigrants are a big reason. Yet you can agree with that statement and still oppose a Democratic plan to let roughly 800,000 noncitizens vote in local elections for mayor, City Council, and so on. The council plans to consider a measure to that end on Dec. 9, and according to the New York Post it has enough support to pass.

title: A Black Path to the Middle Class
summary: New research on the upward mobility of HBCU graduates.. Hard data about the value of a particular degree can be hard to come by. That's why a new study on Historically Black Colleges and Universities is encouraging. It finds that HBCUs are an under-appreciated vehicle for upward mobility for their overwhelmingly African-American students.

title: An Honest Score for the Spending Bill
summary: Sen. John Cornyn wants CBO to report the true cost of the House entitlement blowout.. We've told you about the gimmicks Democrats are using to disguise the true cost of their tax and spending bill, and now a GOP Senator wants the Congressional Budget Office to give an honest cost estimate: "The American people deserve more than smoke-and-mirror accounting from Washington, D.C."

title: American Airlines, Target, Deere: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. American Airlines Group Inc.

title: Peloton Sues Lululemon in Fight Over Clothing Line
summary: Maker of connected fitness equipment said Lululemon's accusations of patent infringement 'lack any merit'. Peloton Interactive Inc . sued Lululemon Athletica Inc., asking a federal court to declare that it didn't infringe on athletic designs, weeks after Lululemon sent a cease-and-desist letter over the bike company's new clothing line.

title: Omicron Identified as 'Variant of Concern'
summary: Variant first detected in southern Africa arrives in Europe and Asia and sparks new travel bans. JOHANNESBURG-A fast-spreading new strain of the coronavirus first detected in southern Africa is a global "variant of concern" and might pose a higher risk of people falling ill with Covid-19 for a second time, the World Health Organization said Friday, as governments around the globe restricted travel from the region.

title: San Franciscans Get What They Voted for With Chesa Boudin
summary: The Weather Underground scion isn't the first district attorney they've elected on a soft-on-crime platform.. San Francisco

title: When Federal Employees Telecommute, Why Are Agencies in D.C.?
summary: The idea of moving offices to the heartland has been floated for years. It's never been more relevant.. The metropolitan area of Detroit has around 1.7 million square feet of vacant office space. Surely there's room for the Federal Highway Administration in all that. With only 41,000 people, Pine Bluff, Ark., has around 41,000 square feet of vacant commercial space. Couldn't the headquarters of, say, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Rural Business-Cooperative Service be squeezed in there somewhere?

title: The COP26 Plan to Keep Africa Poor
summary: We want to help with climate change, but our lives and economies depend on fossil fuels.. As a Senegalese entrepreneur, I can tell you what's holding Africa back: lack of affordable energy. We live on a continent where the average annual income is less than $2,000, and the majority of people rely on fossil fuels for survival. The climate goals wealthy nations demanded at the recent COP26 summit aren't only absurd, they are a death sentence for Africans.

title: Is This a 'Normal' Covid Winter?
summary: Today's surge would be worse if individuals and states hadn't ignored Biden's restrictions on booster shots.. Winter 2021-22 may not quite qualify as our first "normal" Covid season, but we're getting there.

title: U.S. Looks to NATO to Deter Russian Aggression as Ukraine Warns of Possible Coup
summary: Biden administration considers options from deterrence to diplomacy and wants a NATO meeting next week to discuss common actions.

title: The Biden Era of Greed?
summary: Democrats' inflation excuses lead to inconvenient conclusions.. No, this column's headline is not about the latest art show featuring the works of Hunter Biden. This story is about the challenge for President Joe Biden and fellow Democrats in discussing inflation without mentioning its true causes. The politicians running Washington want consumers to believe that behind every price increase is a greedy capitalist.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: T.S. Eliot's defense of tradition, investigating the origin of Covid-19, Beethoven in Boston, holiday reading for mystery lovers and more..

title: Centrist Democrats Signal Opposition to Biden Banking Nominee
summary: Concern conveyed in telephone call with committee chairman, likely scuttling Saule Omarova's chances of confirmation. WASHINGTON-A group of Senate Democrats have privately voiced their opposition to President Biden's nomination of Saule Omarova to become a top banking regulator, likely scuttling the academic's chances of confirmation.

title: 'The Collected Prose of T.S. Eliot' Review: Keeper of the Flame
summary: T.S. Eliot was not only one of the most important 20th-century poets-he defined what poetry of the era ought to be.. If fame is the name of your desire, writing about literature is among the least likely ways to find it. From the 17th century until today, only four literary critics, John Dryden (1631-1700), Samuel Johnson (1709-1784), Matthew Arnold (1828-1888) and T.S. Eliot (1888-1965)-five if one includes that one-man Tower of Babel, Samuel Taylor Coleridge (1772-1834)-have attained enduring reputations. All five also wrote poetry, but, apart from Eliot, it is doubtful if today any would be remembered for his poetry alone.

title: What Happened in Wuhan?
summary: Four books pursue theories of possible origins of the Covid-19 virus-and the question of cover-ups.. The first outbreak of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and the disease that would come to be known as Covid-19 occurred during the fall of 2019 in the Chinese city of Wuhan, but the world still doesn't know the virus's precise origin. Many scientists believe that the most likely explanation is zoonotic spillover, a process in which the virus jumped to humans through another species in the wild. Historical precedent makes the theory plausible-SARS-CoV-1, the virus that caused the 2002-04 SARS epidemic, seems to have crossed over from civet cats. But direct evidence that something similar happened in the case of Covid-19 has yet to emerge.

title: Taming Wild Details
summary: George Stubbs's 'Zebra' is anatomically correct, beautiful and mysterious-a portrait of a true individual.

title: Variant Highlights Risks of Low Vaccination Rates in Poor Countries
summary: The new coronavirus was first identified in Africa, where just 7% of people are fully vaccinated. The identification of a new, highly-mutated variant of the coronavirus virus in southern Africa this week highlights the risk to global public health posed by large, unvaccinated populations in the developing world, where countries have struggled to get immunizations and the virus is spreading and evolving.

title: Covid-19 Variant Upends Investor Bets on Rate Increases
summary: Bond yields slide and investors quickly adjust how swiftly they expect the Fed to raise interest rates. Investors piled into government bonds and quickly recalibrated their expectations for interest-rate increases in response to the new Covid-19 variant first identified in South Africa.

title: Laguna Beach Home on the Ocean Sells for $70 Million to Hedge-Fund Manager Joseph Edelman
summary: The California deal sets a record for Orange County home sales. A New York hedge-fund manager has paid $70 million for an oceanfront mansion in Laguna Beach, Calif., in what agents said is a sales record for California's Orange County.

title: Table Scraps (Saturday Crossword, November 27)
Curly Quote (Saturday Variety Puzzle, November 27)
Interior Department Calls for Higher Fees for Oil-and-Gas Leasing on Federal Lands
summary: Report stops short of proposing ban on leasing on public land or making broader recommendations designed to address climate change. Interior Department officials recommended that the Biden administration consider raising the royalty rate for oil-and-gas leasing on federal lands, as President Biden seeks to deliver on promises to address climate change amid high inflation.

title: How Tax Credits, Subsidies Have Aided Electric-Vehicle Market
summary: The government has pushed to accelerate EV adoption by consumers and car makers; lawmakers now have new incentives in the works. Electric vehicles are getting a lot of attention now. Car companies are quickly refashioning their lineups to incorporate more plug-in models and investors are betting big on Tesla Inc . and other newer challenger brands, such as Rivian Automotive Inc . and Lucid Group Inc.

title: Stocks, Oil Drop Sharply on Concerns Over Covid Strain
summary: Dow finishes its worst Black Friday on record, while Treasury yields slide. Stocks, oil prices and government-bond yields slumped after South Africa raised the alarm over a fast-spreading strain of the coronavirus, triggering concern that travel restrictions and other curbs will spoil the global economy's recovery.

title: P&G Recalls Old Spice, Secret Antiperspirant Sprays
summary: Company is recalling the antiperspirant sprays after it detected benzene in some products. Procter & Gamble Co. is recalling its Old Spice and Secret antiperspirant sprays after it detected benzene, a cancer-causing chemical, in some of the products.

title: Biden's Economic Plans Collide With Inflation Reality
summary: Resume Subscription. WASHINGTON-President Biden took office with a raft of economic plans to better position the U.S. to compete on the world stage and jump-start a labor market ravaged by the pandemic. Ten months into his term, Mr. Biden is facing a new set of economic challenges.

title: Disney Knows Rococo
summary: The studio's beloved movies borrowed broadly from art history but especially from an 18th-century French style of ornamental whimsy. Though young viewers may not realize it, the animators of some of Disney 's most memorable films drew deeply from European visual culture. In "Inspiring Walt Disney: The Animation of French Decorative Arts," which opens Dec. 10, New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art presents more than 200 objects-among them elephant-headed vases, animation cels, preparatory sketches and a miniature room-to illustrate the unlikely process that turned elite art styles into beloved mass entertainment.

title: Oil Price Slumps on Fears of New Covid-19 Restrictions
summary: Fuel prices plummet on news of coronavirus variant. South Africa's warning of a new and fast-spreading strain of coronavirus walloped the energy sector on Friday, leading to the sharpest declines in oil prices since the global economy locked down early last year to slow the spread of the deadly virus.

title: Investors Go Back to Their Early-Covid-19 Playbook: Buy Zoom and Peloton, Dump Travel
summary: Work-from-home companies and Clorox rose, while cruise lines slumped. It was like early 2020 all over again in the stock market Friday.

title: Advent Calendars Have Become Luxury Vending Machines. Is That OK?
summary: Once a humble, fun way to count down to Christmas, Advent calendars now disgorge expensive beauty products, gin, flavors of pork cracklings or $150,000 of Tiffany jewelry. Some Scrooges don't approve.. IF I LIVE to be a very old woman and am tucked into bed in front of a roaring fire, clutching a childhood memento, I expect the last word I mumble will be "Sellmer."

title: Vaccine Mandate Legal Challenges Muddy the Waters for Employers Preparing to Implement Rules
summary: Businesses will need to be flexible as they consider how best to comply. The deadline for requiring U.S. workers to be vaccinated or tested weekly for Covid-19 is fast approaching, but uncertainty about how legal fights over the mandate will play out has left companies in limbo on how best to prepare.

title: Madonna Criticizes Instagram for Removing Photos
summary: Pop-music pioneer says her post was censored because part of her nipple was showing. Madonna publicly criticized Instagram over the company's removal of photos from her page, saying that her post was censored because part of her nipple was showing.

title: Walter Kirn Is Middle America's Defiant Defender
summary: The novelist discusses the Kyle Rittenhouse verdict and urban elites' illiberal attitudes toward those who live between the East and West coasts.. The Kyle Rittenhouse case reminds Walter Kirn of an incident from his youth in rural Minnesota. "I remember one night, as a Midwestern kid out in the country, sitting with a loaded gun at the top of my stairs," he says. A violent inmate had escaped from a nearby prison and was hiding in people's barns. "I was 16," Mr. Kirn chuckles, "and I sat up with a shotgun, probably somewhat delusional, convinced I could protect our farm."

title: The Kippahs on the Yeshiva University Basketball Court
summary: Its star player wants to be the first Orthodox Jew in the NBA.. My 6-year-old son was watching basketball in our kitchen when he grinned at me, pointed at a player's head and said, "Hey, they are wearing kippahs, that's so cool." The players ran down the court passing the basketball to one another, confidently anticipating their teammates' moves. Then guard Ryan Turell made a shot. The Yeshiva University Maccabees celebrated, and we cheered loudly.

title: Alibaba Empowers Business Units to Be More Agile as Challenges Mount
summary: CEO Daniel Zhang is devolving power to unit presidents as competition grows and big platforms come under pressure in China. HONG KONG-Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.'s chief executive, Daniel Zhang, is devolving power to the heads of the company's business units to become more agile in tackling rising challenges and potentially open the way for spinoffs, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Merck's Covid-19 Pill Was 30% Effective in Final Analysis
summary: The drug, which is up for authorization by the FDA, was less effective than the 50% rate reported earlier. Merck & Co. and Ridgeback Biotherapeutics LP said a final analysis of their experimental Covid-19 pill found the drug less effective than an early look, prompting U.S. health regulators to continue a staff review of the drug's application days before an outside panel meets.

title: U.S. Economy Could Enjoy Post-Holiday Glow
summary: Rising Covid-19 cases are a hurdle, but easier hiring conditions and fewer supply-chain snarls could lessen the economy's typical January swoon. By now it is clear that the economy should be closing out the year on a high note, with Americans spending money over the holidays and reengaging in many of the activities that they missed out on during last year's damped-down festivities, even with the emergence of a new virus variant.

title: Stressed by Vacation Planning? These 'Travel Clubs' Promise VIP-Style Service and Perks
summary: Eager to lure wary travelers back into the fold, airlines, hotels, even RV parking sites are rolling out membership plans offering secret deals, insider access and more. MARY-FRANCES DALY has a subscription for most everything. The McLean, Va., life coach uses her Amazon Prime membership for shopping. Netflix and Hulu entertain her on demand. Blinkist keeps her informed by sending summaries of nonfiction books, and Insight Timer, a wellness app, keeps her centered. And this winter, when she takes three of her children to Paris for a stay at the sumptuous Hotel Regina Louvre, she'll rely on yet another subscription-to the travel service Inspirato. For $2,500 a month, Inspirato's Pass program gives upscale travelers access to thousands of homes and hotels, with extra perks and anything-anytime-anywhere concierge service. "I was debating buying a beach condo somewhere, which would have been about the same price as Inspirato," said Ms. Daly, "but I didn't want to be tied to one property."

title: The New Rules of Retirement Spending
summary: A longstanding strategy for funding our golden years is in doubt. We answer readers' biggest questions about how much to withdraw from savings.. The rules that govern retirement spending are changing. No surprise, then, that retirees have lots of new questions.

title: Novelist Ann Patchett Knows the 'Tyranny of Good Deeds'
summary: The author of 'Bel Canto' can't shake her reputation for being 'super-nice'. At age 25, Ann Patchett "slipped out" of her brief first marriage, abandoned the teaching job she shared with her husband at a small Pennsylvania college and moved back in with her mother in Nashville, Tenn. Until that point, her life as an aspiring writer had seemed to follow a script: She studied with the distinguished writers Grace Paley and Russell Banks in college, published a story in the Paris Review before graduating, and refined her craft at the top writing program in the country. Suddenly, she found herself waiting tables at T.G.I.Friday's, serving fajitas to former classmates and wearing a mandatory "funny hat."

title: Siberia Coal-Mine Explosion Kills More Than 50
summary: Russian authorities open probe into suspected methane-gas blast. MOSCOW-Russian authorities opened a criminal investigation into a suspected methane-gas explosion at a Siberian coal mine that killed more than 50 people and left dozens hospitalized, casting a spotlight on a key industry for the country that in recent years has been plagued with accidents.

title: Amazon Trucks Snarled in U.K. Amid Climate Protest Blockades
summary: Protesters targeted 15 facilities in a bid to disrupt Black Friday operations. LONDON-Climate protesters blockaded 13 Amazon . com Inc. facilities in the U.K., as well as two more in Germany and the Netherlands, snarling trucks in some locales, in a bid to disrupt operations on the busiest day of Amazon's year in terms of online orders.

title: Ukraine President Says Russia Is Backing a Planned Coup
summary: Remarks threaten to worsen tensions between Kyiv and Moscow. MOSCOW-Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Russia of backing a plan to overthrow him, in remarks that threaten to aggravate tense relations between Kyiv and Moscow as Western officials warn of a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine.

title: Your Giant Potato Might Set a World Record. Then What to Do With It?
summary: A couple hopes their 16.7-pound spud named Dug wins a Guinness, but its fate is likely in a vodka bottle. "Dug," a contender for the world's heaviest potato, might soon become "Done," the vodka.

title: Chinese Tech Giants Face Economic Drag
summary: With consumption and digital advertising hit, some firms look for new drivers of growth. TAIPEI-China's tech giants are feeling the pinch of an economic slowdown, adding financial pressure to an industry beset by a bevy of new regulations this year.

title: Hate Skinny Jeans? You're in Luck: Flared Jeans Are Making a Comeback
summary: Like Britney Spears and Paris Hilton, Y2K-era bell-bottom jeans are freshly relevant-and their biggest proponents might surprise you. How to wear them today.. "EXCITING" and "definitely new" is how Eliza T. Pendergast described the latest trend sweeping the denim market. Like many of her Gen-Z peers, Ms. Pendergast, a student at Hamilton College in upstate New York, decries skinny jeans. She associates those constricting pants with the peppy stars of Disney shows she loathed as a kid. These new jeans, though, are different. They have a "much better silhouette," said Ms. Pendergast, 19. They lend her outfits a symmetry that makes her feel "balanced." They don't compress her calves. They're flares.

title: On the Front Lines of the Supply-Chain Crisis
summary: Resume Subscription. A ship captain waits for weeks to unload his cargo in Los Angeles. A crane operator in Savannah, Ga., sits above a port jammed with boxes. A trucker in Alabama is handing off cargo in parking lots.

title: John Kerry's Phony Climate Accomplishments
summary: The only thing historic about the Glasgow conference was its cost and carbon footprint.. The comparison by John Kerry of this month's international climate carnival with the Constitutional Convention was preposterous ("COP26 Prepared the World to Beat Climate Change," op-ed, Nov. 22).

title: Orwell Knew the Importance of Being Stupid
summary: The stupid party has its virtues.. John Stuart Mill called the Conservative Party "the stupidest party," Barton Swaim reminds us ("The Impossible Insurrection of Jan. 6," op-ed, Nov. 20). Yet Lionel Trilling, also cited by Mr. Swaim, noted the political advantages of stupidity in his 1952 introduction to George Orwell's "Homage to Catalonia":

title: If Biden Were Like Buffett. . .
summary: His age would be just a number.. In "As Biden Turns 79, a Panic Over Harris" (Review & Outlook, Nov. 20), the editorial board cites a poll of voters that finds 58% think President Biden is "too old to be President." I think the pollster is asking the wrong question. It should be: "Is Joe Biden physically and mentally fit to be president?"

title: Critic of Daylight-Saving Time at Yale Clarifies His Point
summary: Lessening the amount of daylight during waking hours is a valid reason for increased stress and other negative emotions.. I want to make it known that the excerpt from the Yale Daily News ("Notable & Quotable: Darkness," Nov. 20) was completely taken out of context. The author of the article, Yakeleen Almazan, is a close friend, and our interview was conducted in a somewhat informal setting. My comment that I am "victimized" by daylight-saving time, quoted in her article, was entirely a joke. Although that is rather apparent, perhaps it should have been made clearer.

title: Narendra Modi Surrenders to the Farmers
summary: The repeal of three market-friendly agricultural laws will limit upward mobility for India's workers.. For a politician elected for his strong leadership, Narendra Modi is pretty good at abject surrender. Last week he appeared on national television to announce the repeal of three market-friendly farm laws passed by his government last year.

title: Fiction: Scheherazade and Her Repertoire
summary: To match one of the most fantastic feats of invention in literature, the story of how it came to be.. In an empire long ago there lived a king who discovered his wife sleeping with a palace slave. Crazed by jealousy he vowed that henceforth he would marry only for the length of a night and each morning his new bride would be killed. After he had carried out his wicked agenda for some time, Scheherazade, the brave daughter of the king's vizier, demanded that she be the next in line to the royal bedchamber. During the first night she beguiled the time with a fantastic story, breaking off at a moment of high suspense as morning arrived. The king agreed to delay her execution so long as she took up the tale the following night-and the reprieve was extended again, and again, until, after one thousand and one nights, the king saw the error of his ways.

title: How to Build Stronger Relationships With Colleagues in the Zoom Era
summary: Research shows that colleagues who work remotely can develop the same levels of trust as those working face-to-face. It just takes longer.. A year and a half into the pandemic, remote work remains popular, and a recent survey found that 76% of those who work outside of the office want to continue doing so at least part of the time.

title: 'Mr. Beethoven' Review: Prometheus in the New World
summary: The great composer Ludwig van Beethoven arrives in 1830s Boston to premiere a new work based on the Book of Job.. A few decades before the great cultural migration that drove creative artists to the New World in flight from the Russian Revolution and Hitler, the U.S. hosted two of Europe's most important composers. Antonín Dvořák directed New York City's National Conservatory of Music from 1892 to 1895. Gustav Mahler conducted the Metropolitan Opera and New York Philharmonic from 1908 to 1911. Dvořák was a fit for New York; Mahler was not. Dvořák, one learns, was a man at all times marvelously responsive to his environs. Mahler lived profoundly inside his own head.

title: 'Small Things Like These' Review: A Road Through the Mist
summary: The shadow of the Magdalene laundries hangs over a gemlike story of life in a small Irish town.. Midway through Claire Keegan's novel "Small Things Like These," a wife urges her brooding husband to rein in his imagination and leave well enough alone. "Where does thinking get us?" she cautions him. "There's things you have to ignore, so you can keep on." It is a warning that echoes throughout centuries of literature; this could be Jocasta, after all, imploring Oedipus to ignore the conundrum of his birth with "don't give it another thought, don't even think." And indeed, Ms. Keegan's protagonist will tempt fate and, incidentally, stumble on the truth of his paternity. But the setting for this particular drama is rural Ireland in 1985 where the curse upon the land is not plague but unemployment and the entities that rule-and casually ruin-people's lives are not the Greek gods but the far less playful clerics of the Catholic Church.

title: The New World of Pandemic Politics
summary: The crisis has entrenched attitudes toward government among Republicans and Democrats and created unpredictable dynamics for the elections ahead. When the coronavirus pandemic began rampaging through American society in the early months of 2020, it was clear that it would set off a public-health crisis. What few anticipated at the time was its far-reaching impact on the country's politics. Now there can be no doubt: The pandemic and lockdowns have exacerbated the nation's political tribalism, put new issues atop the public's priority list, deepened generational differences and fractured social structures that have helped to hold the body politic together.

title: Children's Books: The Clock Strikes at Midnight
summary: A festival of holiday fun, including snow angels, a Christmas pig and some menorah-lighting llamas.. A young girl wakes in the night to see the walls of her room "pulsing with a strange, glimmering light." Thus begins "Where Snow Angels Go," a captivating illustrated story by Maggie O'Farrell, author of the prize-winning 2020 novel "Hamnet."

title: Five Best: Books on Women at War
summary: Selected by Lucy Adlington, the author, most recently, of 'The Dressmakers of Auschwitz.'. By Svetlana Alexievich Translated by Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky (2017)

title: Do We Need More Heroes? Disney Hopes So.
summary: The Magic Kingdom is betting that it can continue milking popular Marvel, Star Wars and Pixar franchises without souring its audience. That is no sure thing.. Many media and tech giants hope to carve out a place in streaming. Disney 's strategy is to bet you can never have too much of a good thing.

title: Turkey's Central Bank Says Financial System Is Strong Despite Lira Crisis
summary: Report gives President Recep Tayyip Erdogan a reprieve from reversing course on his unconventional policies. ISTANBUL-Turkey's central bank said Friday the country's banking sector remained strong and had enough liquid assets to withstand the currency crisis, taking some pressure off President Recep Tayyip Erdogan to change course on his economic policies.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended November 20
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Authority on Dementia Found New Insight as Patient
summary: Dr. Kazuo Hasegawa looked at the disease from both sides of the doctor's desk, seeking to lessen the stigma around it.

title: Ghislaine Maxwell Trial Will Put Memories of Epstein Accusers on Trial
summary: Defense plans to call memory expert Elizabeth Loftus to cast doubt on accusers' accounts. The reliability of memory is expected to be a big part of the coming criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, which is poised to hinge on testimony of women who say the British socialite helped financier Jeffrey Epstein sexually abuse them decades ago.

title: Thanksgiving Covid Variant Reminds Markets of the Important Things in Life
summary: Debate around inflation has obscured much bigger uncertainties liable to buffet the global economy and steer the actions of central banks. For investors, there is nothing like reports of a new Covid-19 variant over Thanksgiving to put things in perspective.

title: Spam Folders Can Hold Surprises-and Prizes
summary: Maybe check to see if you won a Nobel or own an appliance that explodes. Most of the time, spam filters work very well, shielding us from scamsters, hackers, old girlfriends or boyfriends and con artists masquerading as relatives being held at gunpoint in Syria. But all too often, legitimate emails go to the spam folder, and we miss important communications. Sometimes, the results are disastrous.

title: Zoom Video, Carnival, Peloton, Moderna: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Vaccine makers are jumping on fresh Covid-19 fears while travel stocks are sliding. Global markets are taking a hit on Black Friday amid worries about a new Covid-19 variant-but some familiar names are getting a boost. Here's what we're watching:

title: Maeve Reilly Changed How Women Dress. Now She's Building Her Brand.
summary: Changing street style via her work with Hailey Bieber and Megan Fox was just the beginning for Reilly, who has a new YouTube channel, her own clothing line and a styling class series.. One of the first stops on the office tour Maeve Reilly is recording for her YouTube channel is her gallery wall of press moments: dressing the singer and actor Janelle Monáe for the 2017 Oscars, in an embellished Elie Saab Haute Couture gown, in Vogue; the first time Reilly made the Hollywood Reporter's Most Powerful Stylists list, also in 2017; a Coveteur tour of her closet from 2020. "This was the best gift my ex-boyfriend ever gave me," she tells everyone in the room before deciding not to shout him out in the video.

title: Working From Home Has All Sorts of Annoyances. Here's How I Solved Them.
summary: Slow Wi-Fi. Tied to my desk. I lose track of time. I keep eating. It doesn't have to be this way.. In the war between office and home office, I've picked a camp: I'm Team WFH, all the way. But that doesn't mean I'm impervious to its many annoyances.

title: Biden's Nearly $2 Trillion Social Spending and Climate Bill Is a Boon for Unions
summary: Business groups plan to push back on a prevailing wage rule and other measures when the bill goes to the Senate. WASHINGTON-President Biden's nearly $2 trillion spending bill passed by the House is stocked with benefits for organized labor, including a measure aimed at helping unionized companies win billions of dollars in new green-energy projects.

title: These Cryptocurrencies Could Hit a Bag End
summary: Quick demise of JRR Token should be a warning to coin developers making use of others' intellectual property. Crypto entrepreneurs are overdue for a lesson on what happens when they pilfer others' most precious intellectual property.

title: Baseball Is Heading Toward a Lockout. The Starting Pitcher Market Is Red Hot.
summary: With the offseason barely under way, starting pitchers are cashing in on the free-agent market. Barely a month ago, the role of the starting pitcher in baseball appeared to be on life support. Starters averaged fewer than four innings a game during the playoffs, accounting for just 45% of the total innings-both record lows. The Atlanta Braves even removed a starter partway through a no-hit bid in the World Series, proof of the extent to which bullpens reign in the biggest games.

title: High-Yield Bond Sales Soar to Record
summary: U.S. companies have sold over $455 billion of bonds with junk credit ratings this year, already beating 2020's full-year record. Investors' hunt for higher fixed-income returns has powered sales of low-rated corporate bonds to a record.

title: J&J Covid-19 Vaccine Recipients Shift to Other Boosters
summary: In contrast, most people who originally received the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines have stuck with the same shots if they got boosters. Johnson & Johnson 's Covid-19 vaccine hasn't been the booster shot of choice.

title: Holiday Bargains for Retail Stocks
summary: Shares of apparel sellers with anything less than a stellar outlook are seeing steep selloffs. Investors should smell an opportunity.. Black Friday is here, and apparel sellers with anything less than a sparkly outlook for the holiday season have been trampled.

title: Supply-Chain Woes Snarl Attempts to Tame House Prices
summary: Rising costs of construction materials, labor shortages complicate efforts to cool some of the world's hottest property markets. SYDNEY-Snarled supply chains and labor shortages are adding fuel to some of the world's hottest property markets, complicating efforts by central banks and regulators to cool them down.

title: China Evergrande's Billionaire Founder Sells $343 Million Stake
summary: Sale follows stock-price rout and cuts chairman's holding below 68%. The founder and chairman of China Evergrande Group , Hui Ka Yan, has sold a large chunk of his shares in the cash-strapped property company, raising the equivalent of about $343 million.

title: Supply-Chain Snarls Leave Southern California Swamped in Empty Shipping Containers
summary: From the docks of ports to private yards, stacks of boxes are growing higher and spreading out, adding to the severe gridlock in distribution networks. The biggest export out of Southern California these days is air. And it is suffocating the supply chain.

title: Russian Sabre-Rattling Shakes Ukraine Bonds
summary: Government-debt markets shrugged off earlier Russian troop buildups but this time is different, some investors say. Escalating Russian military activity on the border with Ukraine is rattling foreign investors, pushing prices of Ukrainian government bonds to their lowest levels in more than a year.

title: A Miserable Person's Guide to Watching Michigan vs. Ohio State
summary: Throw the television out the window and go for a walk outside. Just kidding! (Maybe.). Help me.

title: France, Italy Sign Pact Seeking More Influence in Europe
summary: Franco-Italian treaty is aimed at bolstering collaboration on areas such as foreign policy and defense, industrial policy and the EU's fiscal rules. ROME-France and Italy signed a cooperation treaty on Friday that its advocates hope could shift the balance of power in the European Union, matching Germany's influence by deepening cooperation between the bloc's second- and third-biggest members.

title: Jack Ma's Ant Moves Ahead With Credit-Scoring Company
summary: Fintech giant will partner with state-owned companies to establish Qiantang Credit Reporting. Ant Group Co. is setting up a credit-scoring company with state-owned shareholder partners, as the Chinese financial-technology giant presses ahead with its restructuring.

title: The Chinese Metaverse Stock Frenzy Gets Unreal
summary: Chinese stocks related to the metaverse-even very tangentially-have risen sharply. But jumping in now could result in real losses. The metaverse will blend the virtual and physical worlds. Investors should be careful that the meta market frenzy doesn't warp their sense of reality.

title: Tech Gifts Sold Out Before the Holidays. Here's Your Guide to Smart Alternatives.
summary: You waited and popular gadgets started selling out. Don't panic-just follow these steps for successful gift substitutions.. The season's most popular gadgets have been selling out for months. But there are ways to get your hands on them-or smart alternatives-even this late in the game.

title: Brainard's Nomination Promotes a Close Powell Ally on Fed Innovations
summary: Two veteran policy makers must navigate an unexpected jam of higher prices lasting longer. President Biden's decision to nominate Lael Brainard to become Federal Reserve vice chairwoman elevates a veteran policy maker and economist who has been a strong ally of Chairman Jerome Powell on the central bank's boldest policy decisions during the pandemic.

title: Casino Stocks in China's Gambling Hub Are Out of Luck
summary: Macau's gambling stocks have fallen this year as the pandemic keeps the Chinese territory closed off to visitors. Coronavirus flare-ups and a regulatory overhaul are clouding the long road to recovery for China's gambling hub.

title: Taiwan Hosts Second U.S. Congressional Delegation in Two Weeks
summary: The visit comes days after the White House invited Taiwan to a meeting of democracies, exacerbating tensions with Beijing. A delegation of mostly Democratic lawmakers arrived in Taiwan for a two-day trip, marking the second Congressional visit in roughly two weeks at a time of rising tension between Beijing and Washington over the democratically self-ruled island.

title: Japan Approves Extra Defense Spending and Sets a Record
summary: With China in mind, Tokyo budget allots 1.14% of GDP for the military, erasing longstanding guideline. TOKYO-Japan's cabinet approved a boost in defense spending that for the first time will bring the annual total beyond ¥6 trillion, to the equivalent of $53 billion, responding to China's rapid military expansion and U.S. requests for upgrades.
